title: 18 Exterior Paint Color Ideas That Add Major Curb Appeal
description: Whether you go for classic white or a more daring hue, these colors will help your house make a great first impression
author: Elizabeth Stamp, Perri Ormont Blumberg
excerpt: Whether you go for classic white or a more daring hue, these exterior paint colors will help your house make a great first impression
text: All products featured on Architectural Digest are independently selected by our editors. However, when you buy something through our retail links, we may earn an affiliate commission.Exterior house colors may not be the sexiest part of your renovation efforts, but choosing the right exterior paint color can make a big difference. “Repainting the exterior of your home is one of the most impactful and budget-friendly ways to enhance curb appeal,” explains Nina Lichtenstein, founder of Custom Home Design by Nina Lichtenstein in Thornwood, New York. “A new coat of paint can completely refresh the look of your property, creating a polished first impression and potentially increasing its value, especially if you’re preparing to sell. Not only does it improve aesthetics, but it also protects your home’s exterior, making it a smart investment that can last for years.”Consumers have seemingly embraced this ethos and are taking their paint budget outside. According to Marine Sargsyan, a staff economist at Houzz, upgrading a home’s exterior paint is a top priority during outdoor projects. In fact, according to the 2024 US Houzz Outdoor Trends Study, nearly three in five homeowners upgraded their home’s exterior wall surface (58%) this past year.Ahead, here are 18 exterior paint color ideas that are sure to delight and dazzle along with answers to frequently asked questions.What is the most popular color for a house exterior?Among homeowners painting exterior wall colors, Sargsyan shares that the 2024 US Houzz Outdoor Trends Study found neutrals are the top choice, specifically white (23%), gray (19%) and beige (10%). “This is reflective of what we’re seeing in interior spaces, creating a consistent palette for the whole house,” says Sargsyan, who concedes that some homeowners still embrace colors such as black (8%), green (8%), blue (4%), red (3%), yellow (3%), and even orange (1%). “Popular trim colors include white (28%), black (22%), and green (13%),” she adds, pointing out that, perhaps surprisingly, the majority of renovating homeowners (71%) choose a wall color that contrasts with the trim color for their exterior wall color scheme.Echoing that sentiment of neutral color preferences, Lichtenstein shares that one of the most popular exterior house colors right now is a soft, warm white like Benjamin Moore’s White Dove or Sherwin-Williams’s Alabaster. “These shades are gaining popularity not just inside homes but also for exteriors, as they strike the perfect balance between a clean, modern aesthetic and a warm, inviting feel,” she explains. “The versatility of these warm neutrals allows them to complement various architectural styles, and they pair beautifully with darker accents, which adds to their appeal in contemporary and classic designs alike.”Similarly, Eva Lindsell Andersen, principal of Gilded Antler Interiors in Greenville, South Carolina, states that she’s seeing a tremendous amount of white as of late. “Even beyond the modern farmhouse look, clients still want that crisp, traditional exterior. Most are selecting Sherwin Williams Pure White or Benjamin Moore Chantilly Lace for this clean, bright look,” she says. Emily Kantz, color marketing manager at Sherwin-Williams, agrees that Pure White is popular among homeowners. It’s a “versatile, bright white has the slightest yellow undertone that keeps it from appearing too stark.” She also suggests Greek Villa SW 7551, which she describes as a “sunny white that comes to life in natural light, making it the ideal color for exterior, especially on trims to make other colors pop.”According to Kantz, this hue would be fun to pair with a different front door color for a pop of personality. You might want to consider painting your garage door a different color, too. (While painting your entire home exterior may be out of the question, painting your door trim a bright shade or adding white trim around windows may make for a quick weekend DIY project.) Lindsell Andersen also believes that colors with warm undertones work well for the exterior, and suggests shades like Sherwin Williams’s Accessible Beige or Benjamin Moore’s Revere Pewter.What color is best for the outside of a house?The short answer: The best exterior paint color for your home depends on the aesthetic you seek.The longer answer: “The best color for the outside of a house depends on the style, location, and personal preference,” says Lichtenstein. Overall, Lichtenstein, like other designers we tapped, believes that neutral tones like soft grays, whites, and beige tend to be the safest bets. “These colors create a timeless look, enhance curb appeal, and are generally appealing to a broad range of potential buyers,” she says. “Neutrals also provide a great backdrop for bolder accent colors, allowing for flexibility in how you style the exterior with doors, shutters, or landscaping. Additionally, these shades reflect light, making homes look larger and more inviting.”Lindsell Andersen suggests “neutral colors that are appropriate to your particular region.” To that point, she believes warm beiges with brick or stone accents, soft charcoals, and greens are always a beautiful choice. From a practical perspective, Kantz notes that homeowners who live in warm climates year-round might consider going for lighter colors to avoid heat retention that could make the interior of a home warmer and result in higher cooling costs. In general, Kantz also recommends sticking to neutrals, such as whites, grays, and blacks when it comes to exteriors, and adding a touch of your own personality through trims, front doors, and outside decor.What exterior colors last the longest?Another case for applying whites or lighter neutral colors to your home’s exterior: “White paint colors have the longest longevity for exteriors,” says Kantz. “With its ability to coordinate with a variety of architectural styles from modern to traditional, white exteriors have an almost chameleon quality to them because they work with so many different exterior finishes and just about any color combination.” White exterior colors such as Pure White SW 7005, Alabaster SW 7008, or Snowbound SW 7004 are often preferred colors of many that live in the sunnier climates due to the constant sun exposure, she adds.Neutrals have staying powers too. “The lighter colors reflect light and tend to hold up better, whereas a darker color absorbs heat and will fade and age faster than a lighter one,” says Lindsell Andersen. “Darker colors show more pollen and dirt and have to be cleaned more frequently.” Talk with your contractor about any specific concerns various paint colors may present in your area and to get a sense of what hues may have the best durability.What exterior paint colors should you avoid?Again, that’s a matter of personal style preferences so there’s no hard and fast rule for house paint colors that are off the table.Still, paint experts like Kantz recommends keeping this important guideline in mind: “Since exterior painting projects often take up a lot more time, effort, and resources than an interior project, I would recommend homeowners avoid picking colors that they aren’t 100% sure they can see themselves enjoying for more than a few years,” says Kantz. “For this reason, I’d steer clear of colors that seem too trendy at the moment, such as bold or bright shades, and stick to those that have stood the test of time,” she elaborates. If someone feels strongly about adding a bright color to their exterior or one they’re less confident it, she suggests saving that for the front door, which can easily be swapped out over a shorter period.Photo: Scott BergmannDeep OceanIsn’t this shade of blue captivating? “The exterior of this home has bleached walnut and reclaimed wood accents, as well as black windows and board formed concrete,” describes Lindsell Andersen. “We wanted a color that would pull all of those contrasting textures and finishes together, and it needed to look great in all four seasons, especially the long, cold winters in Saratoga Springs [in New York].” That’s why Lindsell Andersen and her team settled on Deep Ocean Blue by Hardie Board: “The blue looks beautiful in the summer against the green leaves and trees, and it’s equally welcoming in the winter framed by gray skies and fresh white snow,” the designer adds.Photo: Aimee MazzengaForest GreenFor this Michigan cottage, Mike Shively, founding partner of En Masse Architecture and Design in Chicago, and his colleagues achieved eye-catching results by applying Benjamin Moore Sherwood Forest 2048-10 on the siding and Benjamin Moore Onyx 2133-10 trim.“The design opted for a home that would blend into the tree line and meadow in the lush green summer months and not distract from its lake setting. In the winter, the home is set apart from the snowy landscape,” says Shively. He also adds that the contrasting black trim was selected to provide articulation and to emphasize the porch-like structure. “Bringing further emphasis to the trim makes the home feel more quaint and cottage-like,” he adds.Photo: Waleed ShahBright WhiteChoosing white as an exterior paint color can make a strong statement, especially when paired with contrasting trim and details. “I took a standard Palm Jumeirah, Dubai, villa and combined it with the cool, natural feel of Mykonos where temperatures can soar to similar heights. We stripped the render off the exterior walls, and curved and smoothed every single corner on the exterior with natural cement,” says Jamie Brooks, cofounder of BBH in Dubai. Then, the team at BBH painted the villa with bright white paint to reflect the sun.Photo: Susan TeareMountain SageAnother project of Lindsell Andersen’s, this lake house haven belongs to an artist and is located on land that had been owned by her family for several generations. “Our custom new construction home is located in a grove full of evergreens, and we wanted a color that was rich enough to stand alone, but also blend in with its surroundings,” Lindsell Andersen says. She opted for Mountain Sage Hardie Board accented by red cedar and Benjamin Moore Black Jack on the trim to “create a modern lake house [that] feels at home in its natural surroundings.”Photo: Pieter EstersohnYellowCasa Verdad, a Palladian-inspired villa in San José del Cabo, Mexico, was created by Marshall Watson Interiors in collaboration with Stephen Morgan Architect. The sunny yellow exterior was chosen to reflect the colors of the landscape.Photo: Drees HomesDark GrayJennifer Harkai, Drees Homes Design Center manager in Nashville, credits PPG’s Summer Shadow shade for providing an opportunity to go bold, “setting our home apart from the typical all-white modern farmhouses commonly found in the area.” Plus, says Harkai, the moody exterior, combined with warm cedar accents, Domino brick and Ironstone fascia and soffit, has been a favorite among those seeking striking curb appeal.Photo: Scott BergmannOff BlackAs Lindsell Andersen shares, the scale of this home required something other than the expected white or red usually seen on a farmhouse. So, the team opted for Benjamin Moore’s Raccoon Fur. “It’s an off-black with violet undertones, which allows it to reflect light in an extremely versatile manner for a darker hue,” she says. “By keeping nearly all the trim monochromatic, we allow the stonework and the copper work to pop against the darker mass of the home,” adds Lindsell Andersen. Fun fact: This historical colonial home now sits at the crest of rolling hills on a thoroughbred farm in upstate New York, but was originally in Vermont.Photo: Brian MaddenBlue-GrayFor a serene exterior paint color choice, consider a bluish gray. Or better yet, various shades of this hue. “Using different shades of blue-gray across various siding styles and architectural elements adds depth and visual interest to your home’s exterior,” says Lichtenstein. Per the interior designer, a darker blue-gray for the main body, chimneys, and prominent features draws the eye upward and around the structure, whereas applying a mid-tone blue-gray to roof peaks and beneath windows can make these elements stand out. She suggests using lighter shades as accents above or below the darker tones to provide contrast and highlight specific architectural features. “White fascia and trim strategically placed throughout enhance these distinctions, emphasizing the layered effect for a sophisticated, cohesive look,” further comments Lichtenstein.Photo: Matthew MillmanMetallic BlackHow about this jewel from AD Pro Directory Member David Thompson, principal and Founder of Assembledge+? This residence is clad in cement board siding, finished in a rich black hue by Benjamin Moore that imparts a subtle metallic sheen to the exterior. “The deep color adds depth, extending the perceived length of the walls and amplifying the sense of spaciousness. Accented with Western Red Cedar and framed by expansive floor-to-ceiling windows, the design exudes a refined, moody elegance, creating a captivating interplay of materials and natural light,” the designer says.Photo: Gavin CaterNeutralsFor the body of this home, Barrett Cooke, principal designer at Arterberry Cooke, an architecture firm based in Los Angeles and Austin, used Barnwood Grey by Behr complemented by Dakota Shadow by Benjamin Moore for the front door. “Both of these colors are timeless, elevated, and elegant. The two colors paired together are not too overpowering and balance each other out,” she says of the elegant yet understated color scheme. “The green door is an earthy neutral color that looks beautiful with the lush greenery that surrounds the home.”Photo: Pascal ChevallierSoft Green Exterior InspirationThe exterior of the Romany caravan that designer Jacques Grange transformed into a guesthouse at Pierre Bergé’s Normandy home is painted in a soft green, allowing it to blend into the landscape.Photo: NativeHouse PhotographyBeigeLori Paranjape, principal designer of Mrs. Paranjape Interiors + Design in Nashville, wows us with this chic tan. “We selected Benjamin Moore Kangaroo AF-145 after extensive sampling,” says Paranjape, adding that she was looking for a tan that didn’t read yellow or red. “I kept coming back to Kangaroo for the rich undertones and velvety appearance,” she continues. Here, Paranjape and her team used the same hue for trim and fascia to avoid creating too much contrast. “For the shingles, we used wood with similar tones to keep the contrast low and further the neutrality,” she comments. The metal tones for the house (gutters, downspouts, windows, and doors) are bronze for a “warmth that we couldn’t get with black metal.”Photo: Andrew WrisleyBrownFor this gorgeous mountain home, Sarah Latham, principal of Latham Interiors in Sun Valley, Idaho, referenced the coloring in local natural stone and wood combinations to clad the exterior in an earthy brown which offsets the dark metal roof and window frames. To better integrate the home into the landscape, “The design team utilized natural elements in the exterior color palette,” adds Latham.Photo: Timothy HursleyRedFor the residence she designed near Lake Michigan, architect Margaret McCurry created a modern interpretation of the farm structures in the surrounding area. The bright cherry exterior is a spin on the traditional barn red hue.Photo: Joshua McHughBlackJonathan Adler and Simon Doonan took a cue from the Rolling Stones and painted their Shelter Island, New York, home black. According to Doonan, they were inspired by the single-story charcoal-colored structures they had seen in Japan and appreciated their ability to blend into the landscape.Photo: Richard PowersGrayFor producer Brian Grazer’s Santa Monica home, architect Mark Rios pared the existing structure down to simple barn-inspired forms and clad the exterior in cedar, which he stained gray to complement the slate roof.Photo: Ngoc Minh NgoPinkThe pale pink exterior of this Bahamian cottage, complemented by crisp white trim, plays beautifully against the lush landscape and the striking turquoise of the adjacent pool. Designed by Andrew Raquet Interior Design, the home also features Chinese Chippendale–style furniture that complements the space’s light and airy feel.Photo: Pieter EstersohnWhiteArchitect Peter Pennoyer and interior designer Katie Ridder chose classic white paint for the exterior of their Greek Revival weekend home in Millbrook, New York, and accented the crisp shade with deep blue shutters.
html:
All products featured on Architectural Digest are independently selected by our editors. However, when you buy something through our retail links, we may earn an affiliate commission.

Exterior house colors may not be the sexiest part of your renovation efforts, but choosing the right exterior paint color can make a big difference. “Repainting the exterior of your home is one of the most impactful and budget-friendly ways to enhance curb appeal,” explains Nina Lichtenstein, founder of Custom Home Design by Nina Lichtenstein in Thornwood, New York. “A new coat of paint can completely refresh the look of your property, creating a polished first impression and potentially increasing its value, especially if you’re preparing to sell. Not only does it improve aesthetics, but it also protects your home’s exterior, making it a smart investment that can last for years.”

Consumers have seemingly embraced this ethos and are taking their paint budget outside. According to Marine Sargsyan, a staff economist at Houzz, upgrading a home’s exterior paint is a top priority during outdoor projects. In fact, according to the 2024 US Houzz Outdoor Trends Study, nearly three in five homeowners upgraded their home’s exterior wall surface (58%) this past year.

Ahead, here are 18 exterior paint color ideas that are sure to delight and dazzle along with answers to frequently asked questions.

What is the most popular color for a house exterior?

Among homeowners painting exterior wall colors, Sargsyan shares that the 2024 US Houzz Outdoor Trends Study found neutrals are the top choice, specifically white (23%), gray (19%) and beige (10%). “This is reflective of what we’re seeing in interior spaces, creating a consistent palette for the whole house,” says Sargsyan, who concedes that some homeowners still embrace colors such as black (8%), green (8%), blue (4%), red (3%), yellow (3%), and even orange (1%). “Popular trim colors include white (28%), black (22%), and green (13%),” she adds, pointing out that, perhaps surprisingly, the majority of renovating homeowners (71%) choose a wall color that contrasts with the trim color for their exterior wall color scheme.

Echoing that sentiment of neutral color preferences, Lichtenstein shares that one of the most popular exterior house colors right now is a soft, warm white like Benjamin Moore’s White Dove or Sherwin-Williams’s Alabaster. “These shades are gaining popularity not just inside homes but also for exteriors, as they strike the perfect balance between a clean, modern aesthetic and a warm, inviting feel,” she explains. “The versatility of these warm neutrals allows them to complement various architectural styles, and they pair beautifully with darker accents, which adds to their appeal in contemporary and classic designs alike.”

Similarly, Eva Lindsell Andersen, principal of Gilded Antler Interiors in Greenville, South Carolina, states that she’s seeing a tremendous amount of white as of late. “Even beyond the modern farmhouse look, clients still want that crisp, traditional exterior. Most are selecting Sherwin Williams Pure White or Benjamin Moore Chantilly Lace for this clean, bright look,” she says. Emily Kantz, color marketing manager at Sherwin-Williams, agrees that Pure White is popular among homeowners. It’s a “versatile, bright white has the slightest yellow undertone that keeps it from appearing too stark.” She also suggests Greek Villa SW 7551, which she describes as a “sunny white that comes to life in natural light, making it the ideal color for exterior, especially on trims to make other colors pop.”

According to Kantz, this hue would be fun to pair with a different front door color for a pop of personality. You might want to consider painting your garage door a different color, too. (While painting your entire home exterior may be out of the question, painting your door trim a bright shade or adding white trim around windows may make for a quick weekend DIY project.) Lindsell Andersen also believes that colors with warm undertones work well for the exterior, and suggests shades like Sherwin Williams’s Accessible Beige or Benjamin Moore’s Revere Pewter.

What color is best for the outside of a house?

The short answer: The best exterior paint color for your home depends on the aesthetic you seek.

The longer answer: “The best color for the outside of a house depends on the style, location, and personal preference,” says Lichtenstein. Overall, Lichtenstein, like other designers we tapped, believes that neutral tones like soft grays, whites, and beige tend to be the safest bets. “These colors create a timeless look, enhance curb appeal, and are generally appealing to a broad range of potential buyers,” she says. “Neutrals also provide a great backdrop for bolder accent colors, allowing for flexibility in how you style the exterior with doors, shutters, or landscaping. Additionally, these shades reflect light, making homes look larger and more inviting.”

Lindsell Andersen suggests “neutral colors that are appropriate to your particular region.” To that point, she believes warm beiges with brick or stone accents, soft charcoals, and greens are always a beautiful choice. From a practical perspective, Kantz notes that homeowners who live in warm climates year-round might consider going for lighter colors to avoid heat retention that could make the interior of a home warmer and result in higher cooling costs. In general, Kantz also recommends sticking to neutrals, such as whites, grays, and blacks when it comes to exteriors, and adding a touch of your own personality through trims, front doors, and outside decor.

What exterior colors last the longest?

Another case for applying whites or lighter neutral colors to your home’s exterior: “White paint colors have the longest longevity for exteriors,” says Kantz. “With its ability to coordinate with a variety of architectural styles from modern to traditional, white exteriors have an almost chameleon quality to them because they work with so many different exterior finishes and just about any color combination.” White exterior colors such as Pure White SW 7005, Alabaster SW 7008, or Snowbound SW 7004 are often preferred colors of many that live in the sunnier climates due to the constant sun exposure, she adds.

Neutrals have staying powers too. “The lighter colors reflect light and tend to hold up better, whereas a darker color absorbs heat and will fade and age faster than a lighter one,” says Lindsell Andersen. “Darker colors show more pollen and dirt and have to be cleaned more frequently.” Talk with your contractor about any specific concerns various paint colors may present in your area and to get a sense of what hues may have the best durability.

What exterior paint colors should you avoid?

Again, that’s a matter of personal style preferences so there’s no hard and fast rule for house paint colors that are off the table.

Still, paint experts like Kantz recommends keeping this important guideline in mind: “Since exterior painting projects often take up a lot more time, effort, and resources than an interior project, I would recommend homeowners avoid picking colors that they aren’t 100% sure they can see themselves enjoying for more than a few years,” says Kantz. “For this reason, I’d steer clear of colors that seem too trendy at the moment, such as bold or bright shades, and stick to those that have stood the test of time,” she elaborates. If someone feels strongly about adding a bright color to their exterior or one they’re less confident it, she suggests saving that for the front door, which can easily be swapped out over a shorter period.
